email_subject: When the going gets tough
html_css_code:
Find out about what the Consumer Federation of America calls agent ‘glut’ and what it means for you and your business

January 09, 2024  |  View in Browser

“If you feel like you've had a down year, you're probably right. But if you've sold two or more homes, you're doing better than almost half of your brethren and sistren in the real estate industry, according to the industry watchdog Consumer Federation of America,” Inman’s Christy Murdock writes in this week’s Download. At the end of each week, Murdock breaks down the top-read news and gives readers what they’ll need to meet Monday head-on.

 

This week she looked at a new report from the CFA that found that about 1.5 million agents are attempting to sell between 5 million and 6 million homes annually. This is a result of what the CFA is calling agent “glut,” meaning that less experienced, part-time agents now outnumber seasoned veterans, causing “widespread incompetence and pressure to maintain high commission rates,” reports Inman’s Andrea Brambila.

 

This is likely due to the rise in Realtor ranks after the pandemic boom when seemingly everyone was getting licensed because houses were selling quickly with very little prep work. And as the CFA points out, it’s not all that difficult to get a license — 26 states don’t require a high school diploma, and $600 is the median cost to get a real estate license.

 

Last week also brought the news that, for the first time in over a decade, the Realtor ranks receded.

 

“National Association of Realtors membership declined by more than 26,000 in 2023, which amounts to a 1.7 percent decline from last year’s ranks. By the end of December, the organization’s total membership had settled at 1.55 million,” Inman’s Daniel Houston writes.

 

Of course, this could somewhat be backlash for the year’s sexual harassment scandal or the commission lawsuits, but also, when the market gets tough, typically, those part-time, inexperienced agents that the CFA describes leave the industry. For many, it doesn’t make sense to pay for membership dues, continuing education, and other fees that go along with doing business when they’re only selling one to two (or zero) houses a year.

 

Part of the reason we’re covering this in today’s newsletter, is that we want you to understand the perception some in the industry have of new or part-time agents. If your competition sees a new agent as inexperienced, you have to be better, smarter and more willing to learn than the rest. And we want to equip you with what you’ll need to move forward. 

 

On The Basics today:

  • 7 massive mistakes most real estate agents are making
  • You sold HOW MANY houses last year? The Download
  • 24 how-tos to help you start 2024 off with a bang
  • 6 side hustles to help you attack an income gap
  • 19 real estate pros share their Lesson Learned moments


 

Check out the latest from Inman Access: Defy the market: Strategies for success from industry experts

 

And please, send us your conundrums, quandaries and queries for Inman’s new agent advice column.

7 massive mistakes most real estate agents are making right now by Jimmy Burgess

The best way to learn is from the mistakes of others, and right now, many agents are making critical mistakes that are leading to business destruction, writes Jimmy Burgess. Here’s how you can avoid their mistakes and fill in the holes they’re creating when committing these errors.  

Read the full story

Top Tip:

 

EXTRA: You sold HOW MANY houses last year? The Download

 

Navigate the complexities of real estate

For expert guidance in this complex market, attend Inman Connect New York. Where seasoned professionals address financing, affordability, tech, AI, negotiation challenges and more. Learn more

DRILL DOWN

24 how-tos to help you start 2024 off with a bang

To formulate this list of how-tos and start the year off right, Inman's Service Editor Dani Vanderboegh rounded up the top advice and most-read contributors of 2023. 

 

5 ARTICLES FOR WORKING WITH BUYERS AND SELLERS

 

  1. 9 ways to get a client to sign a buyer-broker agreement: Don't be a shrinking violet when it comes to your compensation. Broker Cara Ameer teaches you how to ask for what you're worth and have that tough buyer commission talk.
  2. Stop! Before you send that buyer listings, ask these 47 questions: If you don't ask your buyers the right questions, writes broker associate Cara Ameer, before you travel too far down the road with them, you could end up wasting their time and yours.
  3. Up your game with these hot tips from NAR's buyer and seller data: NAR’s 2023 Profile of Home Buyers and Sellers has just been released, and it’s packed with insights that can help you take your business to the next level in 2024. According to trainer Bernice Ross, the most important insights concern your lead generation and lead conversion.
  4. 8 reasons sellers aren't selling (and how to get them off the fence): Interest rates, insurance premiums, tax concerns and more are keeping sellers from putting their homes on the market and forcing them to defer their dreams. Team leader Carl Medford believes it's up to real estate agents to communicate effectively and help sellers move forward.
  5. 5 steps to making money in today’s down market: Helping your clients understand the psychology of a changing market will make the job of selling their home much easier, writes trainer Bernice Ross.

Read the full story here.

 

EXTRA:  Waiting for clients? Here’s what you should be doing

 

6 side hustles to help you bridge an income gap

Although some experts argue that a side hustle is a symptom of giving up, Rachael Hite argues that taking on a side hustle is a sign that you are willing to do whatever it takes to make it, despite challenging circumstances.  

 

This isn’t mission impossible; this is mission we gotta slay to play in 2024. High rates, inflation, and fewer commissions are a reality for many. A side hustle can be a solution to closing the gap and potentially reinvigorating a stalled pipeline.

 

For most agents across the country (even successful ones), business is down between 10 and 30 percent from last year. Don’t let the current market conditions get you down; polish up that resume, and join the multiple-job movement. 

 

Here are six part-time jobs to work your way out of a slump, pump up your SOI and earn a little extra scratch this year. Read the full story here.

 

EXTRA: Inman’s top 10 news stories of the year

DO YOUR HOMEWORK

19 real estate pros share their Lesson Learned moments

 

As you may know, here at Inman, we love to celebrate the hard-working real estate pros — those boots-on-the-ground agents who're pounding pavement, having real estate conversations, and finding buyers, sellers and deals-to-be-had. We also love to learn how they got where they are, the wins they've celebrated and the tough lessons they’ve learned. That's why, since 2018, Inman's Christy Murdock has been sniffing out those agents across the nation to ask them what they know now in a recurring column called Lesson Learned. 

 

This year had its fair share of lessons to learn as the market became more challenging. Along the way, these 19 real estate pros shared their own personal career takeaways and advice for agents in the field facing similar challenges. Read the full story here.

GET ADVICE

Calling all new agents: We want to help solve your problems

Problems, issues and awkward situations are going to come up in real estate, and they're not always easy to solve. Sometimes you don’t know where to turn, but please know, we're all ears. Please send us your questions here. Responses can be anonymous, just let us know your preference. We'll report back with sound advice.

  • Curated content specifically for you
  • Intel on all the Inman happenings that can strengthen your business

And don’t forget about our New Agent News page, the hub for new agents to get what they need.

— LEARN SOMETHING NEW —

  Available 1/23  
If you want to learn how to do something, ask the people who do it well. That's what Dr. Michael Greger did, pulling in evidence from regions where people live the longest and distilling it into an accessible and enjoyable read designed to help you defy your age. From the multi-award-winning performer, author, and activist, a comprehensive program for addressing mental and physical health — and encouraging communities to do the same. And Then We Rise encourages readers to transform their thinking, their actions, and, ultimately, their lives. The latest in the Plant Paradox series offers a definitive guide to the gut biome and its control over its home — us — revealing the unimaginably complex and intelligent ecosystem controlling our health and teaching us how to heal our guts to prevent and reverse every type of disease.
— READ & REFLECT —
SEE ALL FICTION >
Timely, relevant and deeply engaging, The Fetishist boasts dark humor with scathing social commentary that will have you cackling and reflecting on deeper truths. Stylistically written with a delicious panache for good wordplay, this is a read that connects on multiple levels. The looming threat of a wildfire in Greece provides all the impetus this book needs to thrive, with its dynamic characters and genuine human connection. This is an unforgettable story with a massive scope, an exacting tone and words that practically sing off the page. A game gone wrong, leaving one little girl dead and the other haunted by the namesake of the novel. This is a story about facing the truth that is at times devastating and at times hopeful, but at all times sharp and inventive.
— FOLLOW YOUR FANTASY —

Built on real-world allegories, this is an epic fantasy set in a gorgeous and fully realized world that will have readers thinking of Brandon Sanderson alongside the high-intensity political intrigue of the Kushiel series. Epic fantasy and a pirate princess steeped in Indian folklore make for this downright stunning Exclusive Edition featuring gorgeous, stenciled edges as well as special endpapers.

email_subject: Exclusive: Ex-Google CEO Eric Schmidt Is Working On A Secret Military Drone Project
html_css_code:
One of the defense industry’s loudest advocates in Silicon Valley, the billionaire has been planning a covert venture inspired by Ukraine’s use of drones on the battlefield, with the help of Google alum Sebastian Thrun.

FORBES EXCLUSIVE
  ILLUSTRATION BY FORBES; PHOTOS BY MICHAEL MACOR/THE SAN FRANCISCO CHRONICLE/GETTY IMAGES; BELTERZ/GETTY IMAGES, CHEREZOFF/GETTY IMAGES
Ex-Google CEO Eric Schmidt Is Working On A Secret Military Drone Project
Read Article
Ex-Google CEO Eric Schmidt has been quietly plotting a new defense tech effort: a stealth military drone project, four sources with knowledge of the effort told Forbes. The project’s existence has not been previously reported and it has yet to publicly launch.

The clandestine project intends to provide an American alternative to Chinese drones, and will develop unmanned aircraft systems specifically to be used on the battlefield, two of the sources said. Three of the sources familiar with Schmidt’s engagements said the work is influenced by his recent visits to Ukraine, where the billionaire has made inroads with government officials and military leaders over the past year.

email_subject: 3 Labor Market Trends To Watch | How To Beat Back-To-Work Blues | 2023’s Career Crashes
html_css_code:
Plus: Over 305,000 Laid Off In Major U.S. Cuts Last Year—Here Are The Biggest

ADVERTISEMENT

BECOME A MEMBER • Newsletters • MyForbes
Hi Careers readers,

Happy New Year! (Can I still say that even though it’s January 9? I haven’t written to you since last year.) For many, a new year marks new ambitions. Perhaps a 2024 career goal of yours is to find a new job. 

In my latest story, I spoke with economists and labor market experts about what you should expect from the job market in the year ahead. The bottom line? Don’t wait to start your job hunt. Although many employers do still have plans to hire, hiring will continue to slow overall. Plus: Wages and raises will ease up, returning to pre-pandemic norms, while layoffs are expected to remain low. Read more about these labor trends in my story here.

Elsewhere, if you’re like me, it’s your first week back to work post-vacation. Don’t worry: Senior contributor Caroline Castrillon has advice for beating those back-to-work blues. As always, read on for more career advice and workplace news. Have a great week! 

Emmy Lucas Careers General Assignment Reporter

Follow me on Forbes.com

WORK SMARTER
Practical insights and advice from Forbes staff and contributors to help you succeed in your job, accelerate your career and lead smarter

Revamp your LinkedIn with these tips in the new year.

How do you know if you’re on the right career path?

Networking is nerve-wracking. Asking these four questions can help.

When does hiring a career coach make sense?

Returning to work post-holidays can bring some blues, but there are ways to ease the transition.

FEATURED STORY
Want to get your career back on track in 2024? U.S. economists break down three labor trends they expect for the year ahead.   Getty
What Workers Should Know About The Job Market In The New Year
Read More
After years of fears over a looming recession, the economy ended 2023 above expectations: The unemployment rate hit 3.7% in November, the Federal Reserve is eyeing interest rate cuts next year and inflation dropped to 3.1%, down from a peak of 9.1% in July 2022.

After months of layoffs, employers have redefined the right size of their workforce and are looking ahead to slower, steadier growth. Meanwhile, workers are staying put after years of job hopping.

Among employers, “there’s a general optimism toward 2024,” says Dawn Fay, an operational president at Robert Half. “There’s this ambition to rightsize, normalize and get back on track.”

In my latest story, economists break down three labor trends expected in the year ahead and what they mean for workers.

TOUCH BASE
Harvard president Claudine Gay resigned last week. GETTY IMAGES
News from the world of work

Harvard president Claudine Gay resigns: Gay’s sudden resignation came January 2 amid mounting pressure from university donors and lawmakers over plagiarism allegations and criticism over her response to reports of rising antisemitism. Gay’s departure drew both praise and outrage.

Gray divorces: Any Bachelor-franchise fans out there? If so, you probably watched the Golden Wedding last week, which has sparked conversations about later-in-life marriage and gray divorce, a term coined by the AARP to define divorces that occur after age 50. Forbes’ Kelly Phillips Erb looks at why they’re increasing—and their financial consequences.

Career crashes: From hubris and hate speech to bad judgment and even a pinch of bad luck, Forbes’ annual Most Notable Career Crashes list illustrates how even the mightiest can fall. Check out 2023’s list here.

Employee bonuses: Senior contributor Caroline Ceniza-Levine breaks down six types of employee bonuses and how they work.

ADVERTISEMENT

CHECKLIST
Add these books and videos to your to-do list
In this video, Forbes breaks down the latest jobs report. It came in hotter than expected.
In Lukewarm Regards, author Kayla Bray provides a guide to setting boundaries at work.
NUMBER TO NOTE

305,000

That’s how many were laid off in major U.S. cuts in 2023, according to Forbes’ layoff tracker.

2023 was a tumultuous one for layoffs, especially in tech. Forbes’ Brian Bushard highlights the biggest here. If you’re looking for a new job or to grow your career in the new year, consider this advice.
QUIZ
Which space company was hit with a new National Labor Relations Board complaint alleging the company illegally fired eight employees for circulating a letter that outlined workplace concerns and was critical of its CEO?
A.Blue Origin
B.SpaceX
C.Rocket Lab
D.Virgin Galactic
Check if you got it right here.
ACROSS THE NEWSROOM
Forbes' Future of Work newsletter features headlines, insights and ideas about where the world of work is headed next. Sign-up instantly here and we'll see you in your inbox every Monday.

email_subject: Begin Again: The One Thing That Can Change Everything
html_css_code:
Start the process
Begin Again Series:
How to Journal: 12 Styles + Myths & Benefits
The one thing that can change everything.
Bouncing off of the 3 frameworks explored in the intro to the Begin Again series, we break down the habit of journaling as an intentional strategy for bringing awareness to distraction in our life and determining what to focus on for meaningful change. 

The 3 Foundational Frameworks:
  • Simply begin again: If you realize you've become distracted from your habits or goals, don't get demotivated. Clear your head and begin again.
  • All decisions and brainstorming should reflect the four preliminaries:
      • Your life is unfathomably rare, make use of it
      • You will die. Your life is shorter than it seems, act with a sense of urgency while you still can
      • The universal law of cause and effect. If you want change, you must take continual action.
      • Fulfillment is not possible from buying things or being seen as important alone. Don't forget to anchor your ambitions to things that are not based on acquiring money, things, or status.
  • Don't just blindly continue on a path that may not be working. Break your ambitions, goals, or problems down to their base ideas and create previously unknown, innovative solutions using first principles thinking.
It's time to begin again

email_subject: A Hugely Profitable Chinese Opioid Market Or A Multi-Million Dollar Scam?
html_css_code:
Plus: Wickr Is Dead And iPhones Survive A 16,000-ft Drop

ADVERTISEMENT

BECOME A MEMBER • Newsletters • MyForbes
Over the last three years, investigators at the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) have been looking at the operations of a number of online Chinese opioid markets that are shipping bulk quantities of deadly drugs like fentanyl to the U.S. One, called ShanghaiChemicals, appears to have been especially profitable, allegedly making at least $3.5 million in 10 months in 2021, according to a recently unsealed search warrant.

But when the DEA tried to buy some fentanyl from the site, it never arrived. That led the DEA to conclude that ShanghaiChemicals may also be a fraud.

The investigation comes at a time when the U.S. is trying to work with China to stop the trade of illicit narcotics from Beijing to America and Mexico, where the country’s most infamous cartels have become key customers.

Read my full story in Forbes here.

Thomas Brewster Associate Editor, Cybersecurity

Follow me on Forbes.com

The Big Story
  404 Media
Wickr Is Dead
Read Article
Amazon-owned encrypted messaging app Wickr is no more. The once-free app is no longer available to the public, but a professional version continues to be sold to federal government agencies like Customs and Border Protection.

ADVERTISEMENT

The Stories You Have To Read Today
Ukraine’s intelligence agency claimed Russia hacked into surveillance cameras to snoop on air defences before launching missiles.

DNA testing company 23AndMe blamed users who re-used passwords for a breach of 14,000 accounts last year, where hackers leaked the  genetic and personal data of nearly 7 million people. As many as 30 lawsuits have since been filed against the company, TechCrunch reports.
Winner Of The Week
Apple’s iPhones are this week being hailed for their ability to survive cyberattacks… and 16,000-foot drops from the sky. Wired has a story about the surprising usability of Lockdown Mode, which restricts some features in iOS in return for heightened security from spyware, while Bloomberg reports on an iPhone that continued to work despite falling from a Boeing 737 Max after a fuselage panel blew off.
Loser Of The Week
Naval officer Wenheng "Thomas" Zhao was sentenced to 27 months in prison for taking $15,000 in bribes from a Chinese intelligence officer in exchange for photos of unclassified private U.S. military information. The stolen data included plans for U.S. military exercises in the Indo-Pacific region and blueprints for a radar system on a U.S. military base in Okinawa, Japan, Reuters reported.

<strong style="">Ever have a recurring dream you wish you could alter?  </strong>Well, it is possible. It's called lucid dreaming and many people have likely experienced it before without knowing it.<br><br>Regular lucid dreaming can be especially helpful for reducing the frequency of nightmares, as well as insomnia and anxiety. <strong style="">Jane Austen never wed, but she knew the rules of marriage. </strong>Unfortunately,<strong style=""> </strong>her expertise did not come with book royalties that would have allowed her to flourish while she was alive. <a style="color:#000000;  text-decoration: none; border-bottom: 2px solid #ffcc00; " target="_blank" class="msotextlink textlinkhover" href="https://email.nationalgeographic.com/T/v60000018cefa895dd94ae0b6e96c660f0/0a0890a5331a433e0000021ef3a0bcdc/0a0890a5-331a-433e-9b52-c5528b5c9d9b?__dU__=v0G4RBKTXg2GtTHJDsy7ii3waBSrIwMXGZJ7x_OARFKFQAIe3mwx22JG_r9Sy1LWLGyMVrrFIdudbYjwKGAKz6iTAgyV5XAM3SbSN-FzJU9XXpFWtSFRxbGw4nHcgLdnvWYAVcbDlQyQtE1-NmUBscmA==&__F__=v0fUYvjHMDjRPMSh3tviDHXIoXcPxvDgUUCCPvXMWoX_0JoZLAZABQF30xF0sKPois3VqfW5bf1WlfvPhqF6LHwAevOY3NThdBdX9QwFVjuI2dYxmWBOtXYhNU2v5dmxRrN8ImRp7Nc9sPyXutIEdQgBBO-XXdeGz-gdc6NxTfixAXEpPwkHHjlbTw7PoyJ-FKfqg9AFcydMAxPeKUH_AR5jXv7-S5o4dVEusT-3Pts2ld7OXHYfGkQOJ7MJMuL62kdJBwfy4QTLnn4fr4sGHis4Pq_yTFQIHDTVjAzp0pnjmMMcyadq0HzDA6ao_G5ez57KtC_pRN2sBbaVgKFPvRruMkGxe9ORb7DUP2JmZeM_igAkyyBoF4SBsCtvYAIL8ak6XAVQydLSCuvJpzvFoxMlpaGiOWDJmQ3OLMkfk51nliYlYQqDbb1kBVjyMjDsM5WIGP7QRC72-Cg2rwbQnTrbyc9WCF3_51OiZpkXeMuEnaZou_L6BR9bY4684CxnnzXFbVZvHm-OyBrjq0K0Z9m9IZ6TQ17mTu9rSoaQYpMa8exVoP2n7282W9urXPubpPNzYn79eftBaNCGRAQEObv0QpMnAcTPfNpv--M7D8ephdwtnC2FMcT0WnQHl0YpjL"><strong style="">Still, the work from the prolific writer (</strong><em style=""><strong style="">above</strong></em><strong style="">) continues to enthrall fans worldwide</strong></a>, with <em style="">Pride and Prejudice</em> and the other pointed, controlled novels (and film adaptations). <strong style="">Where is this animal hiding?</strong> Camouflage, or cryptic coloration, allows many different animals to blend into their environment. <strong style="">She didn’t play by the rules: </strong>This Roman empress was a master strategist. If she were a man, <strong style="">Agrippina </strong><em style="">(pictured above)</em><strong style=""> </strong>might have been one of the greatest. email_subject: Consumer optimism over rates hits record high, the agent’s guide to fair housing, and rents fall for 3rd straight month

email_subject: Secretary Austin was hospitalized for infection related to prostate cancer
html_css_code:
Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin was hospitalized to treat an infection that was related to earlier surgery for prostate cancer, his doctors said in a statement released by the Pentagon on Tuesday.

Email Not Displaying? Click Here

Breaking News Alert

Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin was hospitalized for infection related to surgery for prostate cancer, Pentagon says
Read more

Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin was hospitalized to treat an infection that was related to earlier surgery for prostate cancer, his doctors said in a statement released by the Pentagon on Tuesday. The statement from officials at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center provides new details about Austin's hospitalization amid a growing controversy over the Pentagon's failure to notify the White House about his condition.

email_subject: Inventory and pricing trends in your ZIP code
html_css_code:
Longtime LL readers know that I periodically go down the real estate rabbit hole to discover what’s happening in various housing markets across America.

Hello, LOs!

Longtime LL readers know that I periodically go down the real estate rabbit hole to discover what’s happening in various housing markets across America. What are the current market conditions in my hometown of Wyckoff, New Jersey? How about Burlington, Vermont, where I went to college? My sister is getting married and potentially moving to Zionsville, Indiana. What kind of market will she face as a homebuyer?

All of this is to say I have access to in-depth housing market trends in every ZIP code in America via Altos Research. It’s a great tool to discover what every ZIP code looks like now, not 60 days ago.  

 

And I want to share it with you. LOs, would you like to see what the inventory/pricing trends look like in your ZIP code? Respond to this newsletter (or email me at james@hwmedia.com) and I’ll provide you the inventory, relisting, median price and price cut trends for one ZIP anywhere in the country. Hope you have a great day!

 

James Kleimann

Managing Editor, HW Media

Home-equity lending blossomed in 2023

Home-equity lending overall found its wings in 2023 as a number of independent mortgage banks ramped up product lines over the course of the year — despite a bump in the road in the third quarter when mortgage rates surged past 7%.

What’s in store for non-QM in 2024?

Presented by Deephaven

Due to a tightened credit market and other factors, non-QM has been more in demand and the interest among lenders is growing.

Kickstart your technology solution selection process

No vaporware. No pressure. No travel. HousingWire Demo Days provide executives and leaders a LIVE preview of the technologies that accelerate originations, decrease risk and optimize margins in a no-pressure environment. Register now

      Sponsored by HousingWire

      CrossCountry adopts FICO Score 10 T for non-conforming loans, MBS issuances

      Cross Country Mortgage claims it is "the first mortgage lender to commit to issuing MBS exclusively based on FICO Score 10 T."

      Mortgage Educators and Compliance acquired by 360training

      360training.com, Inc., an online regulated training provider, acquired Mortgage Educators and Compliance, a mortgage lending training company.

      Opinion: More financing options for ADUs are needed

      There are financing options, grant programs and legislation all designed to help homeowners and builders create much-needed infill housing.

📺 The Tim Ferriss Experiment is back—for free! ​
​Episode #1: Drumming ​
​
✍️ New blog post:
​24 Highlights from The Tim Ferriss Show to Make You Healthy, Wealthy, and Wise in 2024​
​
​🎧 New podcast episode:
​The New Frontiers of Mental Health — Dr. Nolan Williams on Brain Stimulation, Ibogaine, Rapid-Acting Tools for Depression, Enhancing Sports Performance, and More (Brought to you by Nordic Naturals Ultimate Omega fish oil, Eight Sleep’s Pod Cover sleeping solution for dynamic cooling and heating, and AG1 all-in-one nutritional supplement.)​
​
​​​Short descriptions are below.
​
Enjoy!
​

​
📺 The Tim Ferriss Experiment is back—for free! ​
​Episode #1: Drumming ​
​
​I’m thrilled to announce that I’ll be releasing all episodes of my TV show, The Tim Ferriss Experiment, on YouTube— for free. It was a maze to secure the rights, but now it’s done.
​
​This is episode #1! The show is like MythBusters meets Jason Bourne. In every episode, I partner with the world’s best and most unorthodox teachers (e.g., Laird Hamilton, Marcelo Garcia, Stewart Copeland), who train me for a final gauntlet. Shocking breakthroughs, injuries, epiphanies, and disasters are all part of the journey. Along the way, I show you how to replicate results in an attempt to prove that “you don’t need to be superhuman to get superhuman results… you just need a better toolkit.” Make sure to subscribe to my YouTube channel to get notified of all upcoming episodes.

🎧 New podcast episode:
​The New Frontiers of Mental Health — Dr. Nolan Williams on Brain Stimulation, Ibogaine, Rapid-Acting Tools for Depression, Enhancing Sports Performance, and More

Welcome to a very special episode of The Tim Ferriss Show, an episode that might be an example of peeking around corners and catching a glimpse of the future of mental health treatments in the next five to ten years.

My guest is Nolan Williams, MD (@NolanRyWilliams). Nolan is an associate professor within the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences at Stanford University School of Medicine and director of the Stanford Brain Stimulation Lab. He has a broad background in clinical neuroscience and is triple board certified in general neurology, general psychiatry, and behavioral neurology and neuropsychiatry. Themes of his work include examining spaced learning theory and neurostimulation techniques, development and mechanistic understanding of rapid-acting antidepressants, and identifying objective biomarkers that predict neuromodulation responses in treatment-resistant neuropsychiatric conditions.

Nolan specializes in looking at cutting-edge treatments and new technologies that can be applied to treatment-resistant psychiatric disorders—so, treatment-resistant depression, disorders that are notoriously difficult to address, such as OCD, and many others.

Nolan’s work resulted in an FDA clearance for the world’s first noninvasive, rapid-acting neuromodulation approach for treatment-resistant depression. And I’ve tested this myself, and we get into this in the conversation. He has published papers in Brain, American Journal of Psychiatry, and Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Results from his studies have gained attention in Science and NEJM Journal Watch. He has received two NARSAD Young Investigator Awards, the Gerald L. Klerman Award, and the National Institute of Mental Health Biobehavioral Research Award for Innovative New Scientists.

We also discuss things like ibogaine that are seemingly unrelated to neuromodulation, as Nolan is very well-versed in multiple disciplines and in multiple toolkits, both pharmacological and non-invasive neuromodulatory. It’s this combination, actually, this rare Venn diagram, that makes him incredibly interesting to me.

I really enjoyed this conversation. I think it is very important, highly tactical, and I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

P.S. “Magnesium–Ibogaine Therapy in Veterans with Traumatic Brain Injuries” is now live in Nature Medicine.

Listen to the episode on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, Overcast, Podcast Addict, Pocket Casts, Castbox, Google Podcasts, Amazon Music, or on your favorite podcast platform. Watch the interview on YouTube here.
​

​

​

​

This episode is also brought to you by Nordic Naturals, the #1-selling fish-oil brand in the US! More than 80% of Americans don’t get enough omega-3 fats from their diet. Plus: what to read this week.

January 9, 2024

Reading on the ski slopes: a new level of bookish introversion to aspire to. Raphaelle Macaron

By Joumana Khatib

Hi readers,

Nine days into the new year and I’m already impatient: antsy to see some snow, eager for time to speed up, hungry for something that feels truly new.

I’m preparing to move apartments, so even my reading right now is retrograde. Rather than packing, or cleaning, or doing something that’s actually useful, I’m tearing through my shelves, picking up books I’ve not yet read in the hopes I can offload them to a good home instead of paying movers to carry them up three flights of stairs.

I have my eye on a few recent novels I’ll reward myself with, once the move is behind me: “Beautyland,” by Marie-Helene Bertino, which our critic Alexandra Jacobs loved, and Álvaro Enrigue’s “You Dreamed of Empires” (ditto Dwight Garner), translated by Natasha Wimmer.

Hopefully you have fewer demands on your time right now and have plenty of hours (and square footage) for new books. As always, you’re welcome to tell me about your reading life: Drop me a line at books@nytimes.com.

See you next week.

LOOKING FOR YOUR NEXT BOOK TO READ?

What Book Should You Read Next?

Finding a book you’ll love can be daunting. Let us help.

By The New York Times Books Staff

18 New Books Coming in January

A look at the Trump-DeSantis rivalry, a witty tribute to “Murder on the Orient Express,” a memoir of open marriage and an epic Swedish novel in verse, among others.

By The New York Times Books Staff

Leon Edler

Audiobooks

Audiobook of the Week: Safiya Sinclair’s Rhythmic Incantations

Reading her audiobook memoir, “How to Say Babylon,” the poet gives voice to her Jamaican roots, her early ambition and the Rastafari father who would have quashed it.

By Lauren Christensen

Continue reading the main story

ADVERTISEMENT

In other news

  • Utah is a place of paradoxes, full of terrible beauty and complicated history. The writer Terry Tempest Williams recommends books to help you explore the state’s many facets.
  • In “How to Be a Good Savage,” Mikeas Sánchez preserves her language, Zoque, through poetry and allows it to commingle with English and Spanish.
  • With plagiarism all over the news, it might be easy to forget it’s also an engrossing plot device. Here are 5 books that explore this fraught terrain.

RECENT BOOK REVIEWS

Fiction

In ‘My Friends’ an Exile Finds Himself Outside Libya, but Never Far Away

A rash decision to attend an anti-Qaddafi protest in London reverberates in Hisham Matar’s poignant and quietly suspenseful third novel.

By Peter C. Baker

Fiction

Waiting in the Snow for a Phone Call, Mixing Memory and Desire

Cynthia Zarin’s first novel, “Inverno,” is a tale of a woman’s incurable longing and haunted past.

By Sigrid Nunez

Fiction

Two Friends Reunite. One Has a Secret.

In “Goldenseal,” Maria Hummel takes readers into a hotel room, then unfurls her characters’ complicated history.

By Emily Barton

Nonfiction

What Happens When a Woman Wronged Resorts to Violence?

In “The Furies,” the journalist Elizabeth Flock reports the stories of three women who fought back — to defend themselves, other women or their people.

By Sanam Maher

email_subject: Wednesday Briefing: Trump’s immunity claim in court
html_css_code:
Plus, 52 travel destinations for 2024
View in browser|nytimes.com
Continue reading the main story

January 10, 2024

By Amelia Nierenberg

Writer, Briefings

Good morning. We’re covering a hearing on Donald Trump’s immunity and a year of record heat.

Plus, 52 travel destinations.

Donald Trump after a court hearing yesterday. Susan Walsh/Associated Press

Is Trump immune from criminal charges?

At a hearing in Washington yesterday, judges expressed deep skepticism about Donald Trump’s claim that he was immune from charges of plotting to subvert the 2020 election. Trump’s lawyers argued that he should not face prosecution because the charges stem from actions that he took as president.

The panel of three federal appeals court judges peppered one of Trump’s lawyers with tough questions about the immunity claims. Trump — who is on track to win the Republican presidential nomination — was there, but did not speak.

One judge seemed less than persuaded that Trump was upholding his constitutional duty to preserve the integrity of the election when he sought to overturn his loss.

“I think it’s paradoxical to say that his constitutional duty to take care that the laws be faithfully executed allows him to violate the criminal law,” said Judge Karen Henderson, the sole Republican appointee.

Here are five takeaways.

The issue of immunity is likely to reach the Supreme Court, which is already hearing another crucial question about whether Trump can be removed from state ballots. The pace and outcome of the immunity question will be central in deciding when, or whether, Trump will go to trial in the election interference case, which is scheduled for March. It could also help determine the timing of his three other criminal trials.

That timing could have a major impact on the 2024 presidential race. A recent poll found that nearly a quarter of his supporters think he should not be the Republican nominee if he is found guilty of a crime. “In a close race, it might be decisive even if only a sliver of voters refuse to vote for a felon,” our top political analyst has suggested.

A ‘frightening’ future: One of the judges asked whether a president could be criminally charged for ordering U.S. soldiers to assassinate a rival. Trump’s lawyer said a prosecution would be possible only if the president had first been found guilty in an impeachment proceeding.

In his response, the lawyer representing the government warned of “an extraordinarily frightening future” if a president could order the military to murder a rival and then escape criminal liability.

Background: Here’s a timeline of Trump’s pattern of pressure to overturn the 2020 election.

The New York Times

The hottest year on record

Last year was Earth’s warmest — by far — in a century and a half. Month after month, global temperatures shot past records.

Scientists also said that 2023 appeared to be among the warmest in at least 100,000 years. And this year could be even warmer.

“There were simply no cities, no books, agriculture or domesticated animals on this planet the last time the temperature was so high,” said an E.U. scientist. Researchers are trying to understand whether 2023 foretells many more years in which heat records are not merely broken, but smashed.

Greenhouse gas emissions are the main driver of global warming. But El Niño, the recurrent weather pattern, didn’t start until midyear — which means that it may not have been a main driver of abnormal warmth, scientists said. This year it could be.

Supporters of former Prime Minister Imran Khan in Islamabad last year. Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times

Election disinformation will rise to new heights in 2024

False narratives and conspiracy theories have evolved into a global menace, and around half of the world’s population is preparing to vote in major elections this year. It’s a pivotal moment for rampant disinformation.

Foreign influence campaigns target polarizing domestic challenges. A.I. has supercharged propaganda efforts and distorted perceptions of reality. And major social media companies have scaled back their safeguards and downsized election teams ahead of contests that will affect how the world is run for decades.

Continue reading the main story

ADVERTISEMENT

THE LATEST NEWS

Asia Pacific

An air-raid alert about a Chinese satellite that flew over Taiwan airspace yesterday. Ann Wang/Reuters
  • A warning from Taiwan about a satellite, erroneously called a missile in English, raised concerns about Chinese harassment before elections on Saturday.
  • South Korea outlawed the breeding, slaughter and sale of dogs for meat. The practice had already lost popularity in recent years.
  • A U.S. naval officer who sent military photos and plans to a Chinese intelligence officer was sentenced to more than two years in prison.
  • India and the Maldives traded insults on social media after Prime Minister Narendra Modi posted a photo from his vacation on Lakshadweep, a nearby island paradise.

The War in Gaza

  • Secretary of State Antony Blinken, in meetings with Israeli officials, said that Israel had “real opportunities” to strengthen ties with Arab nations.
  • Times reporters entered Gaza with Israeli troops. They glimpsed the destruction wrought by Israel’s war — and by Hamas’s operations.

Around the World

  • Gabriel Attal, France’s new prime minister, is the first openly gay person in the post. At 34, he’s also the youngest.
  • U.S. lawmakers called for an investigation into G42, an Emirati A.I. company that works with U.S. tech firms and, they claimed, has ties to China’s military.
  • NASA said it would delay its first crewed moon missions in decades, moving a trip around the moon to September 2025 and a landing to 2026.

Other Big Stories

Sinead O’Connor performing in Vancouver in the late 1980s. Mandel Ngan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
  • The Irish singer-songwriter Sinead O’Connor died of natural causes, a coroner ruled.
  • Investigators said that a panel might not have been properly attached before it blew out of an Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 in midair last week. United Airlines also found loose bolts on similar Max 9 panels.

A Morning Read

A wildlife photographer in Wales caught a mouse decluttering his backyard shed. Animal News Agency

For months, someone — or something — had been tidying up a retiree’s workbench in Wales after him, placing miscellaneous items in a small box. So he set up a night-vision camera to capture the helper.

“Lo and behold,” he said, “I got a video of the mouse.”

We hope you’ve enjoyed this newsletter, which is made possible through subscriber support. Subscribe to The New York Times.

ARTS AND IDEAS

Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times

52 places to go

Every year, the Travel desk offers up a list of travel spots. This year’s list features an elephant rehabilitation program in Kenya, sea-sculpted monoliths in Quebec and a lesser-known home of masterpieces in Italy.

Here are some more picks:

Mustang, Nepal: This ancient Himalayan kingdom is a bastion of traditional Tibetan culture, preserved for centuries by its remoteness. Visitors can take wilderness treks through mountain ranges and visit the well-preserved medieval fortress of Lo Manthang.

Yamaguchi, Japan: It’s called the Kyoto of the West, but this compact city has considerably less “tourism pollution.” The Rurikoji Temple is a national treasure, and Yamaguchi’s winding lanes offer pottery kilns, chic coffee shops and counter-only restaurants.

New Zealand, by train: Road-tripping via camper van is a free-spirited traveler’s dream. But a simpler and more sustainable way to go is by train, which can take you past volcanic peaks, world-class vineyards and dolphin pods.

Find more inspiration here.

RECOMMENDATIONS

Johnny Miller for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Rebecca Jurkevich.

Cook: This frittata is easy and cheesy.

Drink: What makes a wine “good”?

Exercise: Yoga blocks are more versatile than you might think.

Dare: Go ahead. Wear a matching sweatsuit.

Play Spelling Bee, the Mini Crossword, Wordle and Sudoku. Find all our games here.

That’s it for today’s briefing. See you tomorrow. — Amelia

We welcome your feedback. Send us your suggestions at briefing@nytimes.com.

    <div class="column" style="border-top: none; overflow: hidden;">
      <table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; border-spacing: 0; color: #202121; font-family: Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 1.2; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 16px; background-color: #F1F2F3;"><tr style="Margin: 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0;"><td class="inner contents text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; width: 100%; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; text-align: left;">
            <p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: center; word-break: break-word; Margin-top: 0;"><strong>Jan. 9, 2024</strong></p>
<p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: left; word-break: break-word;"><strong></strong></p>
<ul style="Margin-bottom: 48px;"><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;">Phillips' coffee has run cold: "Sometimes if you build it, they don't come"</li><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;">Appeals court probes limits of Trump's broad immunity claim in 2020 election case</li><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;">How Texas officials stymied nonprofits' efforts to help migrants they bused to northern cities</li></ul>
<p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: left; word-break: break-word;">The Pentagon said Tuesday that Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was hospitalized to treat an infection related to an earlier surgery related to that diagnosis. It's the fullest disclosure yet on Austin's condition after days of questions when it was revealed over the weekend that the Pentagon didn't notify the White House about his condition. Meanwhile, the 2024 campaign continues, as Republicans try to overcome the snow and cold in Iowa with the state's caucuses less than
 a week away. <strong>Ed O'Keefe </strong>joins "America Decides" from Iowa at 5 p.m. ET with the latest, anchored by <strong>Caitlin Huey-Burns</strong>. Plus, CBS News will have complete coverage of the Iowa Caucuses on Monday. Watch special live coverage on Monday on CBS, CBS News.com, and stream continuing live coverage on the free CBS News app.</p>
<p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<span class="embed embed--type-image embed--float-none embed--size-large" style="Margin: 30px 0; padding: 0; display: block; float: none;">
  <span class="img ">
<img src="https://assets3.cbsnewsstatic.com/hub/i/r/2024/01/09/2047cc3a-8205-4a31-b987-dea7f6ce3f20/thumbnail/680x453g2/2847973774cfe3dc2b431e54d66c6ee5/gettyimages-1857905595.jpg?v=3638d056f7798fc8425d74271bc0b398#" alt="Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin speaks during a joint press conference with Israel's defence minister in Tel Aviv on Dec. 18, 2023. " align="absbottom" height="453" width="680" srcset="https://assets3.cbsnewsstatic.com/hub/i/r/2024/01/09/2047cc3a-8205-4a31-b987-dea7f6ce3f20/thumbnail/680x453g2/2847973774cfe3dc2b431e54d66c6ee5/gettyimages-1857905595.jpg?v=3638d056f7798fc8425d74271bc0b398 1x,
 https://assets2.cbsnewsstatic.com/hub/i/r/2024/01/09/2047cc3a-8205-4a31-b987-dea7f6ce3f20/thumbnail/1360x906g2/724cc9fe7e1312f99dfa699267aae0b3/gettyimages-1857905595.jpg?v=3638d056f7798fc8425d74271bc0b398 2x" style="border: 0; display: block; height: auto; max-width: 100%;"></span>
</span><p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: left; word-break: break-word;">Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin was hospitalized for infection related to surgery for prostate cancer, Pentagon says</p>
<p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: left; word-break: break-word;">Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin was hospitalized to treat an infection that was related to earlier surgery for prostate cancer, his doctors said in a statement released by the Pentagon on Tuesday.</p>
<p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: left; word-break: break-word;">The statement from officials at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center provides new details about Austin's hospitalization amid a growing controversy over the Pentagon's failure to notify the White House about his condition.</p>
<p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: left; word-break: break-word;">The prostate cancer was detected early last month and Austin underwent a "minimally invasive procedure" on Dec. 22 to treat and cure the cancer, according to the officials. He was placed under general anesthesia and "recovered uneventfully" from the surgery, the statement said. The cancer "was detected early, and his prognosis is excellent," the officials said.</p>
<p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: left; word-break: break-word;"><a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=d9dfde1c3b859706bfa1d0ca2f9b5f18a85a25ec03066832175547384dab49d871ab51523e9495c592ceb03cfdd4837ebd3b4037bc70efa2" data-ftag-appended="" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">Read more</a> from <strong>Eleanor Watson</strong> and<strong> Caitlin Yilek </strong>and 
<a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=d9dfde1c3b859706d098c1496ba0992edb870672dc6a17ffa87ae5038395e9992a7d5432b5db60afb4dd04e338d0b83c62b1045e9824ae24" data-ftag-appended="" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">read a timeline</a> of Austin's hospitalization from <strong>Eleanor Watson</strong>.</p>
<p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: left; word-break: break-word;"><strong></strong></p>
<hr style="Margin: 48px 0; border: 1px solid rgba(225, 5, 0, 0.75);"><p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;"></p>
<p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;">Phillips' coffee has run cold: "Sometimes if you build it, they don't come"</p>
<span class="embed embed--type-image embed--float-none embed--size-large" style="Margin: 30px 0; padding: 0; display: block; float: none;">
  <span class="img "><img src="https://assets1.cbsnewsstatic.com/hub/i/r/2024/01/09/c523e62c-2cbd-45f3-af45-2d15f76ba655/thumbnail/680x907/74172cb92b85ef5ec15e132b92100f82/dean-philips-nh.jpg?v=3638d056f7798fc8425d74271bc0b398#" alt="dean-philips-nh.jpg " align="absbottom" height="907" width="680" srcset="https://assets1.cbsnewsstatic.com/hub/i/r/2024/01/09/c523e62c-2cbd-45f3-af45-2d15f76ba655/thumbnail/680x907/74172cb92b85ef5ec15e132b92100f82/dean-philips-nh.jpg?v=3638d056f7798fc8425d74271bc0b398 1x, https://assets3.cbsnewsstatic.com/hub/i/r/2024/01/09/c523e62c-2cbd-45f3-af45-2d15f76ba655/thumbnail/1360x1814/f4d02bf92f94f4f40f543e7aaf63c654/dean-philips-nh.jpg?v=3638d056f7798fc8425d74271bc0b398 2x" style="border: 0; display: block; height: auto; max-width: 100%;"></span>
</span><p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: left; word-break: break-word;">Rep. Dean Phillips, the self-admitted "longshot" in his primary challenge of President Biden,  and several staffers braved below-freezing temperatures Tuesday morning at the Doubletree Hilton in Manchester, New Hampshire, as part of his "coffee conversations" series, hoping to connect with young Granite State voters attending the New England College Convention. The only problem? Nobody showed up,<strong> Jacob Rosen</strong> 
<a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=d9dfde1c3b8597061cf77ca63d51248ff362733de66acf824732811761a7f12a6bfe16e4d0db92df464b297a3083c6dcebd3e01de58dabe2" rel="nofollow noopener" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">reports</a>.</p>
<p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: left; word-break: break-word;">"Sometimes if you build it, they don't come," Philips told Rosen and the single other reporter in attendance.</p>
<p class="text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; -webkit-hyphens: auto; hyphens: auto; text-align: left; word-break: break-word;">Phillips and his campaign wrapped the event quickly and headed to their next stop, a "housing policy" press conference, also outside, in Manchester.</p>

                <p class="h1 title" style="Margin: 30px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-weight: bold; line-height: 26px; font-size: 20px; letter-spacing: 1px; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; display: none;">America Decides - Newsletter - Content - Placeholder 2</p>

  </tr><!-- Begin Rich Text --><tr style="Margin: 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0;"><td class="one-column content rich-text" style="Margin: 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0;">
    <div class="column" style="border-top: none; overflow: hidden;">
      <table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; border-spacing: 0; color: #202121; font-family: Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 1.2; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 16px; background-color: #F1F2F3;"><tr style="Margin: 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0;"><td class="inner contents text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; width: 100%; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; text-align: left;">
            <p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none; Margin-top: 0;"></p><hr id="horizontalrule" style="Margin: 48px 0; border: 1px solid rgba(225, 5, 0, 0.75);"><p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;">On and Off the Trail:</p>
<ul style="Margin-bottom: 48px;"><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;"><strong>Nikki Haley ramps up criticism of Donald Trump days away from Iowa caucuses: 
</strong>Republican presidential candidate Nikki Haley on Monday night ratcheted up her criticism of former President Donald Trump as she attempts to close the gap between them in the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary, the first two nominating contests of the 2024 election. "I think that Trump has copped out because he used to get it right and now he's turning around and he's getting it wrong wanting to be an isolationist," Haley said at the town hall in Des Moines Monday night, defending her stance on support for Ukraine's military. She was responding to a question at a Fox News town hall from moderator Martha MacCallum that noted that her opponents -- Trump, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis and entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy -- are "on the other side" of the issue and more concerned about
 security at home. <a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=9216015aab9556aeab988c140ebb371d9d4d0f666184fd8c45509667e8ba4a6d9a7cbcf06cdab2df31fbe9a4f4875529621f53a4d7c7fe40" data-ftag-appended="" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">Read more</a> from <strong>Nidia Cavazos</strong>, who has been following Haley's campaign.</li><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;"><strong>RFK Jr. backs out of his own birthday fundraiser gala after Martin Sheen, Mike Tyson said they're not attending: 
</strong>Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is backing out of his own birthday fundraiser gala after celebrity guests Martin Sheen, Dionne Warwick, Mike Tyson and Andrea Bocelli, who were reported to be attending, instead saying that they would skip it. The gala is hosted by the super PAC American Values 2024, which backs Kennedy's presidential candidacy, and another PAC. Kennedy press secretary Stefanie Spear confirmed to CBS News that the independent candidate will not be attending the birthday event. This was first reported by <a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=9216015aab9556ae81d1aa31655cd6443c609e9da0590d3d64eefec42412fc49ee24bdc2fb6089d56039348c991da1de61c482f0cc382bcd" rel="nofollow noopener" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">U.S. News & World Report
</a>. The Kennedy campaign previously told CBS News it didn't have "anything to do with organizing this event." <a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=9216015aab9556ae6369c2128ec85ac7f415e76c25e6fa9c2291c617daa83b53d3576e991ccf6ccec22a18c365a690a69fbd555e651cc158" data-ftag-appended="" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">Read more</a> from <strong>Cristina Corujo</strong>, who has been covering Kennedy's campaign.</li><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;"><strong>Sleigh all day for 2024 candidates as snow blankets Iowa ahead of caucuses: </strong>The big story in Iowa six days before the caucuses is the snow.  A messy winter storm is disrupting the final days of the Republican race and causing candidates to cancel some events. Is it going to affect turnout on caucus night, too? 
<a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=9216015aab9556aefa4d1ba05611c414f4a21734dff9b94c2863165e684c539b2d3233a726e9480c1310f9e64cd86f41a94bc03d4b334b87" rel="nofollow noopener" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">Watch <strong>Taurean Small's </strong>social report</a> from Des Moines.</li><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;"><strong>DeSantis delivers State of the State address before resuming campaign:
</strong> Gov. Ron DeSantis delivered his State of the State address, ahead of heading back to Iowa, as the Florida Legislature opened its annual 60-day session. DeSantis' speech in the state House chamber, which offered few new details of priorities for the 2024 legislative session, formally launched the 60-day session and came six days before the crucial Iowa caucuses in the fight for the Republican presidential nomination. While he did not directly discuss the presidential campaign, DeSantis repeatedly tried to contrast Florida with other states and the federal government on a variety of issues, such as public safety, financial management and immigration enforcement. "Together, we will keep Florida free and provide hope for a revival of the American spirit throughout these United
 States," DeSantis said as he closed the 35-minute speech. <a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=9216015aab9556aef5f9676735f69c434cada91e114dd168249568b5f1bc6e0d500d69c43d7b4760dbd5f1657db8807b02deb69155a796cd" data-ftag-appended="" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">Read more</a> from CBS Miami. </li></ul></td>
        </tr></table></div>
  </td>
</tr><!-- End Rich Text --></table><!--[if (gte mso 9)|(IE)]></td>     </tr></table><![endif]--></div>

  </tr><!-- Begin Rich Text --><tr style="Margin: 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0;"><td class="one-column content rich-text" style="Margin: 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0;">
    <div class="column" style="border-top: none; overflow: hidden;">
      <table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; border-spacing: 0; color: #202121; font-family: Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 1.2; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 16px; background-color: #F1F2F3;"><tr style="Margin: 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0;"><td class="inner contents text" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; width: 100%; color: #202121; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: 0.2px; line-height: 1.375; text-align: left;">
            <p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none; Margin-top: 0;"></p><hr id="horizontalrule" style="Margin: 48px 0; border: 1px solid rgba(225, 5, 0, 0.75);"><p class="h2" style="Margin: 20px 0; padding-bottom: 0; padding-left: 0; padding-right: 0; padding-top: 0; font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: -0.2px; color: #101010; text-decoration: none;">More Politics Stories</p>
<ul style="Margin-bottom: 48px;"><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;"><strong>Appeals court probes limits of Trump's broad immunity claim in 2020 election case: 
</strong>A federal appeals court questioned the limits of a broad claim of presidential immunity put forward by former President Donald Trump, peppering his attorney with extreme hypothetical scenarios during contentious oral arguments on Tuesday. Trump's attorney argued that presidents are immune from criminal prosecution for actions taken in office, unless they are first impeached by the House and convicted by the Senate. The three-judge panel on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit asked whether that argument would apply if the president took a range of clearly illegal actions, including ordering the assassination of a political rival or selling pardons. 
<a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=9216015aab9556aee631639adfda48bbfbff7797130f3882c170b8383a95a1739e2dbb9c279f20a3123e646b1285c86e61107ad4ac68bd43" data-ftag-appended="" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">Read more</a> from<strong> Melissa Quinn</strong> and <strong>Robert Legare</strong>, and watch <strong>Scott MacFarlane</strong>'s report from outside the courthouse on "America Decides" at 5 p.m. ET.</li><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;"><strong>How Texas officials stymied nonprofits' efforts to help migrants they bused to northern cities:
</strong> As an unofficial network of migrant advocates worked to bring organization and efficiency to bus arrivals in cities around the U.S., Texas officials quietly tried to thwart them, maximizing chaos for the Democratic-led cities where the buses were sent, a CBS News investigation has found. Two years ago, to draw attention to the failure of the federal government to come up with policies to stem the flow of migrants across the southern border, the Republican governor of Texas, Greg Abbott, initiated Operation Lone Star. Part of that was a plan to put migrants crossing the southern border on buses and send them north -- and drop them off en masse in cities led by Democrats.  
<a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=9216015aab9556ae8fd69cb328adc65e990bb31f7c5a9041b64df568957b5ddb5a291eb58f327f1ace28c767b0af1b130dffab432d2baa31" data-ftag-appended="" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">Read more</a> from <strong>Manuel Bojorquez</strong> and <strong>Chrissy Hallowell</strong>, and watch the full investigation <a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=9216015aab9556aec5de48ddd36ff2a1970eb3701b811ea732ff7f71ae989c178053b9384cea6f034bc630eeba8380c4b1b0d828c75710a6" data-ftag-appended="" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">here</a>.</li><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;"><strong>Special counsel Jack Smith and Judge Tanya Chutkan, key figures in Trump 2020 election case, are latest victims of apparent "swatting" attempts: 
</strong>Special counsel Jack Smith and U.S. District Judge Tanya Chutkan, two key figures in the 2020 presidential election case against former President Donald Trump, were victims of apparent "swatting" attempts in recent weeks, joining a growing number of public figures targeted with the hoax phone calls. Local police were called to Smith's home near Washington, D.C., on Christmas Day after a false report of a shooting, though they were informed he is under federal protection and did not respond. The FBI has warned that "swatting" calls are dangerous to law enforcement and victims surprised by authorities descending upon their homes. 
<a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=9216015aab9556ae0c67cd3b29c570d2e67eb7d367ef992ccd755ea911badf286eba73ba38744f99894a2ab0acf0565d0227f7148a1f79c6" data-ftag-appended="" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">Read more</a> from <strong>Robert Legare</strong>, <strong>Pat Milton</strong> and <strong>Melissa Quinn</strong>. </li><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;"><strong>High stakes lawsuit pits the town of Vail against hundreds of trucking companies
</strong>: The Town of Vail is under fire over an ordinance aimed at ridding its Vail Village and Lionshead neighborhoods of all delivery trucks.The Colorado mountain town says the trucks create environmental and safety concerns. So, a year ago, it banned most of them and hired a local business to do deliveries using electric carts instead. It gave truck drivers two choices -- park outside the village and carry in their merchandise or pay thousands of dollars to have an electric cart deliver it for them. "We know of no other ordinance like this in the country," says Greg Fulton, head of the Colorado Motor Carriers Association, which represents 650 trucking companies. 
<a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=9216015aab9556ae4a9b9e5fc2150c0b483d4ef5ab7c07c92c9e5fd327b7f9e43862834f4c01aea627337ee284d4f3fc04ce12c5bc1a2e4e" data-ftag-appended="" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">Read more</a> from CBS Colorado's <strong>Shaun Boyd</strong>.</li><li style="Margin-bottom: 8px;"><strong>President Biden's bond with former Congresswoman Eddie Bernice Johnson of Dallas: 
</strong>President Biden traveled more than 1,500 miles to pay his respects to former longtime Dallas Congresswoman Eddie Bernice Johnson, who died at the age of 89 on New Year's Eve. While he did not speak at the prayer service Monday night, his presence served as a reminder of the bond he shared with EBJ, as she was known. They worked together on a variety of issues over the past several decades, and she supported his efforts once he ran for higher office. When Mr. Biden ran for president, Johnson was one of the first elected officials in our area to endorse him in July of 2019. 
<a href="https://click.email.cbsnews.com/?qs=24224094ab75a092ba56578b4fd1f9832225aa20d6e06ab0266675e61dcad3ea5e344ab5e65e500e59527049557b662ca89d5adf91411c4f" data-ftag-appended="" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="" style="color: #202121; font-size: 16px; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">Read more</a> from CBS Texas' <strong>Jack Fink</strong>. </li></ul></td>
        </tr></table></div>
  </td>
</tr><!-- End Rich Text --></table><!--[if (gte mso 9)|(IE)]></td>     </tr></table><![endif]--></div>
